Findings.Issue: Computer account delegation allows unconstrained Kerberos usage
Findings.Description: One or more computer accounts permit unconstrained delegation, enabling ticket theft.
Findings.Impact: Attackers can impersonate any user after compromising a delegated host.
Findings.Remediation: Remove unconstrained delegation and scope to specific services using constrained delegation.

Findings.Issue: Fine-grained password policy permits weak passwords
Findings.Description: Minimum length below 12 characters and no complexity requirement detected.
Findings.Impact: Reduced resistance to password spraying and credential stuffing.
Findings.Remediation: Increase minimum length to 14+ characters and enable complexity per Microsoft guidance.

Findings.Issue: DNS security settings permit anonymous zone transfers
Findings.Description: Primary DNS zones allow AXFR to any host without restriction.
Findings.Impact: Adversaries can enumerate sensitive hostnames and service records.
Findings.Remediation: Disable zone transfers to unauthenticated hosts and restrict to authorized secondaries.

Findings.Description: Privileged group membership count is above the policy limit of 30 accounts.
Findings.Impact: Increased blast radius for credential theft or token misuse.
Findings.Remediation: Review privileged roles, remove stale accounts, and implement JIT elevation.

Findings.Issue: AzureADSSOACC Kerberos key older than 45 days
Findings.Description: Seamless SSO computer account keys have not been rotated within the 30-day window recommended by Microsoft.
Findings.Impact: Expired AzureADSSOACC keys weaken Kerberos SSO integrity.
Findings.Remediation: Rotate AzureADSSOACC keys via Azure AD Connect or PowerShell to maintain SSO integrity.
